qas.question: In the United Kingdom, what is awarded to people who help fund the parties?
Who was discovered to be selling peerages?
What act did parliament put into place to stop such corruptions?
What did the Honours act do?

answers.text: outright sale of peerages and similar honours became a criminal act

qas.question: How did people attempt to overcome this law?
What is awarded to people in the UK who manage loans for a living?
What did Lloyd George help people acquire in his earlier profession?
What do people become a member of if they help people get approved for a loan?
What can people who approve loans for a living take part in in government?

context: In the United Kingdom, it has been alleged that <a0_0><b6_0>peerages<b6_0/><a0_0/> have been awarded to contributors to party funds, the benefactors becoming members of <b8_0>the House of Lords<b8_0/> and thus being in a position to participate in <b9_0>legislating<b9_0/>. Famously, <a1_0>Lloyd George<a1_0/> was found to have been selling peerages. To prevent such corruption in the future, Parliament passed the <a2_0>Honours (Prevention of Abuses) Act<a2_0/> 1925 into law. Thus the <a3_0>outright sale of peerages and similar honours became a criminal act<a3_0/>. However, some benefactors are alleged to have attempted to circumvent this by <a4_0>cloaking their contributions as <b7_0>loans<b7_0/><a4_0/>, giving rise to the <b5_0>'Cash for Peerages'<b5_0/> scandal.
